EAD was imported spring 2019 as part of the ArchivesSpace Phase II migration.
Finding aid was updated by Catherine C. Ricciardi. A few files of additional material were added to the collection.
Finding aid was updated by Catherine C. Ricciardi. Description of digital materials in Series VIII added.

did.langmaterial: Material is in English and in French, with some materials in Dutch, German, Hebrew, Italian, Korean, Norwegian, Polish, Slovenian, and Spanish..

physdesc.extent: 21 document boxes, 1 record storage carton, 1 card file box, 6 custom book boxes, and 1 temporary box

did.abstract: Pamela Moore (1937-1964) was an American novelist, best known for Chocolates for Breakfast (1956). The papers contain correspondence, clippings, contracts, diaries, drafts, manuscripts, memorabilia, photographs, notebooks, notes, outlines, proofs, school materials, sketch books, and a collection of published editions of Moore's novels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in seven series and several subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Digital files can be accessed upon request via a secure laptop in the Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Reading Room. Otherwise, this collection has no restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Some materials currently housed in a temporary boxes will be reboxed, but all items are accessible at this time. Please note that the final diary has a very fragile binding and should be handled with care.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: Pamela Moore (1937-1964) was an American novelist, best known for Chocolates for Breakfast (1956). Although Moore's career was short, the collection contains a wealth of documentation about her life and writings during this period. The papers contain correspondence, clippings, contracts, diaries, drafts, manuscripts, memorabilia, photographs, notebooks, notes, outlines, proofs, school materials, sketch books, and a collection of published editions of Moore's novels.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: The collection also includes materials related to Moore's unpublished works, including articles, novels, short stories, plays, and poetry. The collection contains a significant amount of materials for both Prophets Without Honor and Kathy, including contracts, notes, notebooks, outlines, typescripts, and other materials. These are also working files for several other projects that include character sketches, notes, synopses, and manuscripts of varying lengths. There are also typescripts for poems and several short stories, and some materials related to ideas for plays. The collection includes notes, typescripts for both published and unpublished articles, as well as copies of Moore's published articles. In many cases, Moore's unpublished works are untitled, so some manuscripts may be found to be related to one another or to larger novel projects upon further examination of the available records.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: The collection includes contracts, outlines, typescripts, setting copies, and other materials related to Moore's published novels. The collection lacks a full typescript for render"italic">The Exile of Suzy Q, but includes working files with typescript pages. For Chocolates for Breakfast and The Pigeons of St. Marks / East Side Story / Diana, which went through some revisions, there are multiple typescripts and revisions in the collection. There are several published editions of all of Moore's novels in the collection, as well, primarily of foreign editions of her works.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: The collection also includes material related to Moore's professional activities, including correspondence, contracts, clippings files, financial records, photographs, and memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: Moore's papers contain many personal materials, including books, correspondence, diaries, financial records, a passport, photographs, receipts, school records, sketchbooks, and travel notes. These records shed light on Moore's relationships with her husband, her family, and with Edouard de Laurot, among others. Later correspondence and notes by others also shed light on Moore's life and work. Lastly, Moore's diaries provide insight into her family life, emotional life, relationships, social life, travel, writings, and ultimately, in her final diary entries, her suicide.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: The collection includes printed materials related to Moore's life and work. There are several editions of Moore's published novels; these are primarily foreign editions. The editions include original editions of Moore's novels, as well as foreign editions based upon the Harper Perennial edition of Chocolates for Breakfast (2013). The printed materials also include several books owned by Moore, several of which are inscribed to her, or signed by her. A few of these also relate to equestrians who knew and worked with Moore.

scopecontent.head: Summary
scopecontent.p: A copy of the catalog prepared the literacy agency for this collection is included with the papers. The catalog provides more detailed subject information and context on correspondence, diaries, manuscripts, and other materials in the collection. While the final arrangement and organization of the collection differs from the catalog, it is still a valuable resource.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Pamela Moore Papers; Box and Folder (if known); Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University Library.

userestrict.head: Terms Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. The RBML maintains ownership of the physical material only. Copyright remains with the creator and his/her heirs. The responsibility to secure copyright permission rests with the patron.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: 2017.2018.M104: Source of acquisition--Kevin Kanarek (Represented by Sarah Funke-Butler). Method of acquisition--Purchase; Date of acquisition--2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Pamela Moore was born on September 22, 1937, the daughter of Donald and Isabel Moore (née Walsh). Both of Moore's parents were writers. They had married in 1934, and Isabel's young daughter, Elaine, had adopted Moore's surname after their marriage. By the mid-1940s, the Moores had divorced, and Pamela Moore split time between her father in California and her mother in New York.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: While studying at Barnard College, Moore published her first book Chocolates for Breakfast in 1956. The first American edition of the book was published in September 1956, at the start of Moore's senior year. As Moore had planned to spend her senior year in France, she had already left the county when the edition was published in the United States. The novel became a bestseller not only in the United States, but also in Italy and France. The book went into multiple printings and was translated into several languages. The book gained notoriety for its content, which was uncommon for the 1950s, and it was compared to Bonjour Tristesse by Françoise Sagan at the time. Moore spent much of the next two years in Europe, returning to the United States in the spring of 1958.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore was educated at Rosemary Hall (now Choate Rosemary Hall) and Barnard College. While Moore was matriculated with the Class of 1957 at Barnard College, it appears that she received her diploma in 1958 from the records in the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore married Adam Kanarek shortly after returning to the United States in 1958. The couple settled in New York, where Kanarek was studying at Brooklyn Law School. They had one son, Kevin, in 1963.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore wrote another novel during this period, Prophets Without Honor, but it remains unpublished. Moore had started this novel in Europe, and it was based upon her relationship with Edouard de Laurot, whom she had met on her way to France in 1956. Knopf had bought the novel based upon an outline, but rejected the finished manuscript when it diverged significantly from the original outline and ultimately rescinded its contract.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore published three additional novels after Chocolates for Breakfast but none of these matched the success of her first novel. Moore's next novel was rejected by American publishers, and published as Les Pigeons de Saint Marc by Julliard in France (1960) and as East Side Story by Longmans (1961). The book received favorable reviews in France and was reviewed in the Times Literary Supplement in the United Kingdom, but it did not receive much notice otherwise. The development of a screenplay for Chocolates for Breakfast was also explored during this period, but ultimately the project did not move forward. Moore's next novel, L'Exil de Suzy-Cœur, was published only in France (1962), and Moore and Kanarek travelled to Europe for its publication. Moore's last novel, The Horsy Set, was published by Simon & Schuster in 1963, but it did not sell well, and did not receive reviews in prominent magazines or literary publications.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore continued to write, and began work on a novel tentatively titled Kathy, which had grown out of her revisions to Prophets Without Honor. The novel remained unfinished at the time of Moore's death.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Moore died by suicide on June 7, 1964, at her home in New York City.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Papers processed by Catherine C. Ricciard in October 2018. A small addition of a few files was processed in November 2019.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding aid written by Catherine C. Ricciardi in November 2018, and revised in November 2019.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. Contact rbml@columbia.edu for more information.

did.unittitle: Series I: Manuscripts and Related Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes manuscripts as well as related materials such as drafts, notes, notebooks, outlines, and proofs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contracts for first editions were originally filed with the corresponding manuscripts, and are included in this series. Additional contracts are filed in Subseries II.2: Contracts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In general, any related correspondence is filed in the professional correspondence files in Subseries II.1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains contracts, drafts, manuscripts, outlines, and proofs for Moore's four published novels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first American edition of Chocolates for Breakfast was published by Rinehart in September 1956, with the French edition being published by Julliard soon after, in November. A second French edition, the "nouvelle édition" that included new revisions by the author, was published in 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes a contract, drafts, excerpts, typescripts, and the setting copy for the first American edition. There is also a file of working material for the Nouvelle Edition, which came to the collection from Eddie de Laurot, the son of Edouard de Laurot. In addition, there are proofs and related correspondence for the Harper Perennial Edition, published in 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are some early short stories related toChocolates for Breakfastin Subseries I.3: Short Stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note on pencil (not by Moore) associates the character of Bill in this story with the character of Barry in the novel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pages 2-283.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The original clean version of the typescript carbon that became the setting copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annotated, with substantial corrections. Pages that were cut are included in the setting copy, with pencil lines through the pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This contains about 2" of working material, primarily of inserts and the preface. Substantial annotations. In English and in French.

did.unittitle: Harper Perennial Edition--Proofs and Related Correspondence (Folders 1-5, of 8)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several sets of proofs, with some related cover letters, for the reissue of Chocolates for Breakfast in 2013.

did.unittitle: Harper Perennial Edition--Proofs and Related Correspondence (Folders 6-8, of 8)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several sets of proofs, with some related cover letters, for the reissue of Chocolates for Breakfast in 2013.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.1.2: The Pigeons of St. Marks / East Side Story / Diana

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The working title for this novel wasThe Pigeons of St. Marksand it was published asLes Pigeons de Saint Marcby Julliard (1960). It was published asEast Side Storyby Longmans in the United Kingdom (1961) and later asDianaby Dell in the United States (1964). The Dell contract (1963) is included in this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries includes an outline, sample copy, and the setting copy and the long galleys for the Longmans version. The revised manuscripts were possibly circulated to American publishers, such as Fawcett.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Outline, with 2 pages typescript notes reviewing the outline, and 4 pages of handwritten notes following the outline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wrapper notes that this is the "1st copy of original Pigeons manuscript. No edition was made from this." 244 pp. ribbon typescript on onion skin, largely stamped by Odette Arnaud, and "Exemplaire de Press / Sample Copy."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wrapper notes that this is a "Copy of Pigeons manuscript original version from which the Brisith edition was set. 244 pages"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Marked Proof" with proof reader marks in blue ink.

did.unittitle: Pigeons of St. Marks--Revised Copy for Fawcett

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With envelope.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pages 298-307 (Chapter 17) only.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.1.3: The Exile of Suzy Q

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes the contracts with Julliard (1961) and Paperback Library (1963), as well as a cover proof, and a file with various typescript pages, corrections, and drawings of maps. The collection does not include a full typescript or proof for this book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is related material in Subseries I.7: Drafts and Fragments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes the contract and setting copy, both for Simon & Schuster.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.2: Unpublished Novels and Novellas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains contracts, outlines, drafts, manuscripts, notes, notebooks, and related materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prophets Without Honorwas to have been Moore's second novel. Knopf purchased the novel based upon an outline submitted by Moore and Laurot, but ultimately rescinded its contact in 1959. Both the contract and the rescindment are in this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries also includes outlines, various typescripts, and a portion of the final version (Chapter 7-end, only).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is related material in Subseries I.7: Drafts and Fragments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials related to other unfinished novel projects. Most of these, with the exception of "Rosemary", had working titles. It is unclear if any of these were related to Moore's other writing projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes outlines, character sketches, synopses, and typescript chapters and pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is the original enclosure for the Northscape materials, above.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This was untitled. Includes approximately 150 typescript pages, maps, and notes. It appears that this and Summer Stage might be the same story.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescripts for the first chapters. It appears that this and Rosemary might be the same story.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains drafts and typescripts for several short stories. Many of the stories are untitled, and most are undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title on typescripts is "Battle of Brooklyn Heights." Envelope lists title as "Baby Shoes."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Their Bones Nourish No Sacred Groves
What is General Lee Going to Do?
Pompeiian Red / At Sea / Nina the Arabic Scholar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three short pieces; originally housed in one envelope.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a set of fiction stories. The set includes "Veteran," "Just an Incident," "The Girl with the Long Hair," "Easter Sunday," "Charm Boy," "The Land," "Haven," "The Lost Gold Mine," "A Full Love," "Bad Actor," and "Motherland." "Bad Actor" is an early story related to Chocolates for Breakfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains one set of poems, written between 1950 and 1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a set of poems. The set includes "To the Midnight Caller," "The Night," "Night's Call," "My Evening," "Reason," "A Love of Youth," "Letter to My Fiance," and "La Nuit Vient."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains outlines, a few typescript pages, and notes for two undated plays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A few typescript pages, outline, and notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript pages, outlines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This contains materials related to both published and unpublished articles, and includes typescripts, notes, and clippings of published articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains various materials, including notes for Prophets Without Honor and other stories, various typescript pages, interview questions, and some miscellaneous correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various unidentified typescript pages and notes. A few relate to Professor Mundy and Prophets Without Honor, and there are notes on Simon and Sylvie.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.8: Other Notes and Notebooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains notebooks and notes on various subjects.

did.unittitle: Clippings on Young Socialites and Partying

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This notebook contains some notes related to Kathy, as well as serving as a personal notebooks with notes on her childbirth classes, shopping lists for the hospital, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This notebook contains notes on Bourgeois Realism, Truman Capote vs. French intellectuals, and a draft of story "Pompeii in Red."

did.unittitle: Notes on "Women Who Drink Too Much"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on articles by Neal Gilkyson Stuart from Ladies Home Journal and Readers Digest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, contracts, clippings files, and items Moore received from her publisher René Julliard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are also some professional topics covered in the correspondence, financial, tax, and legal files in Series III: Personal and Biographical Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes correspondence with individuals, literary agents, and publishers, on a variety of professional issues. This correspondence was largerly maintained in one alphabetical set. The correspondence also includes condolence letters, mostly from professional contacts, written to Adam Kanarek after Moore's death in 1964, and a few folders of fan mail and correspondence from readers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries also includes some later correspondence with Adam and Kevin Kanarek on subjects related to Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and other materials related to Edouard de Laurot are filed in Series III: Personal and Biographical Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence to Moore on reactions to the novel Young Assassins; correspondence on Prophets without Honor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a 2011 email to Kevin Kanarek with Arrabal's recollections of Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: French literary agent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence on the reissue and screenplay for Chocolates for Breakfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Burrell was a professor in the History Department at Barnard College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains several condolenece letters to Adam Kanarek following Moore's death in 1964. There are others in the individual correspondence files. The file also contains a bill for Moore's funeral and related expenses from Campbell Funeral Home.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence pertains to the rejection of Exile of Suzy-Q.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lenz was Moore's teacher and friend at Rosemary Hall. The character of Ms. Rosen in Chocolates for Breakfast is based on Lenz. Correspondence includes her reaction to the novel, a letter of condolence, and a later letter to Adam Kanarek regarding his wish to put a stone marker on Moore's grave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding the submission and rejection of Exile of Suzy-Q. Includes comments from readers at the company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Literary agent. Includes agreement and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Martin had written an early article about Pamela Moore; Nedelkoff contacted her about his own writings about Pamela Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Literary agent. Includes correspondence pertaining to Chocolates for Breakfast, including reader's comments from Ladies Home Journal and Women's Home Companion.

did.unittitle: New York Times Sunday Book Review

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains typescript of a review of Gombrowicz's Ferryduke and a carbon of Moore's letter to the editor of the Sunday Book Review. Includes a clipping of the published letter to the editor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of Jaguar magazine from December 1964 which includes an article on Moore. Also includes correspondence from Smith to Adam Kanarek with a litter from Don Fine (editor at Dell) to Smith with his recollections of Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains contracts, signed and unsigned, for various editions and licensing rights to Moore's works. There is also a file of contract copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contracts for first editions remain filed with their corresponding manuscripts in Series I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily consists of clippings related to the publication of Moore's novels: many were obtained from a clippings service. These are primarily in English and in French, although there are some items from the German and Italian presses, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are also some later articles (2000-2014) related to Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping on the junior riders at the National Horse Show; includes photograph of Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily in French. Includes some clippings in German, Italian, and other languages.

did.unittitle: Chocolates for Breakfast--Clippings on Paperback Release; Screenplay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes short clipping on the book's release in paperback edition. Includes several clippings on the development of the screenplay for the novel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two issues of the magazine; include mentions of Moore in articles about current writing.

did.unittitle: East Side Story / The Pigeons of St. Marks--Goyanarte Catalog
East Side Story / The Pigeons of St. Marks--Clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In English, French, Polish, and Italian. Includes a few typescript translations from French publications.

did.unittitle: East Side Story / The Pigeons of St. Marks--Manuscripts/Typescripts of Related Items

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These items were originally together in one plastic enclosure, filed in the clippings files. This folder includes typescripts of interview questions and answers, quotations, carbons of a few rejection letters from publishers, and a handwritten copy of an article published in Brazil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In French. Includes a short article on Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In English and in French.

did.unittitle: Robert Nedelkoff, "The Remainder Table" The Baffler #10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article on Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Chocolates for Breakfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Magazine includes article on the reissue of Chocolates for Breakfast. In French.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.4: Julliard--Promotional Materials and Souvenirs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains items that Moore received from her publisher René Julliard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moore received several items whenChocolates for Breakfastwas published in France: a scarf, a set of dishes, and three matchbooks that were created as promotional items for the book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two other items appear to have been issued as "souvenirs" after the death of René Julliard in 1962: a book, titledEn Souvenir de René Julliard(1963), and a paperweight, which has an accompanying card on the stationary of Madame René Julliard (1964).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Matchbooks featuring the book's cover and a picture of Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: French publisher René Julliard gave items to Moore to celebrate release of Chocolates for Breakfast in France, including this set of plates. The plates include signatures of authors and artists related to the publishing house. Moore's set has 11 8" plates. There should be 12 plates; #5 is missing from this set.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Silkscreen scarf designed by Bernard Buffet, depicting book case of titles published by Julliard in 1956, including Chocolates for Breakfast.

did.unittitle: En Souvenir de René Julliard. Paris: Julliard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Book. René Julliard, founder of Julliard, died in 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lucite paperweight with green feather pen and René Julliard's signature. It includes handwritten card in French, indicating that the paperweight was created in memory of Julliard, who died in 1962.

did.unittitle: Series III: Personal and Biographical Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal and family correspondence, diaries, official documents, school files, sketchbooks, travel notes, and a set of financial, tax, and legal files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs are filed in Series IV: Photographs.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.1: Personal Correspondence and Related Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence and related materials such as clippings, magazines, and personal documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence involving members of Moore's family. The correspondence is between Moore's family and Pamela Moore, Adam Kanarek, and Kevin Kanarek, with the exception of a few items sent to Isabel Moore by Jerry Asher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence written during Moore's lifetime, as well as later correspondence between her family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries also contains a few other items – clippings, draft cards, postcards, and a life insurance policy – related to individual family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Isabel Moore, Pamela Moore, and Adam Kanarek. Also includes a photocopy of a typescript of what are apparently Elaine's notes/quotations from a memoir by Isabel Moore, going back to Isabel's childhood and ending with the end of her marriage to Don Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes obituaries.

did.unittitle: Donald Moore--Correspondence with Pamela Moore, and to Adam Kanarek

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asher was an MGM publicist and later a fan magazine writer.

did.unittitle: Isabel Moore--Forgive Me, My Darling--Advertisement and Memo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isabel Moore wrote a memoir regarding Pamela Moore, but there are no known copies of the book. According to the "In the Next Room" essay in the Harper Perenniel edition of Chocolates for Breakfast, it was never published, although there were advance advertisements. There is a 9-page memo in the file with quotations and notes from the text in this file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven postcards. One was mailed to Adam Kanarek in 1953; the others are unsent.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.1.2: Edouard de Laurot, and Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence from Moore to Laurot, as well as clippings, and several issues of Film Culture magazine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence file for Laurot is a photocopy of the original file kept by Jonas Mekas; Mekas retains the original file. This file contains correspondence from Moore to Laurot (given to Mekas for safe keeping by Laurot) and from Laurot to Mekas, some of which concern Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries also contains clippings on Laurot and Mekas, and copies of Film Culture magazine, which they co-founded in the 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries also contains a few miscellaneous files kept by Pamela Moore. There is also a file of correspondence with journalists and friends in France. One of these dates to Moore's time in Paris. These files include business cards, clippings, correspondence, notes, drafts, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies in this file were provided by Jonas Mekas, who retains the originals. This file contains correspondence from Moore to Laurot (given to Mekas for safe keeping) and from Laurot to Mekas, some of which concern Moore.

did.unittitle: Edouard de Laurot--Draft of Letter to Mr. Borde

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, with notes by Moore.

did.unittitle: Edouard de Laurot and Jonas Mekas--Clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains notes, drafts, fragments, receipts, business cards, etc. dating to Moore's time in Paris. There are a few later items: a letter from school friend Barbara Montgomery to Alison Ehringer with her recollections about Moore and Adam Kanarek (1982) and a short postcard from George Morris to Kevin Kanarek (2013).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a few pieces of correspondence, and sketches of furniture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains correspondence, notes, articles, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains six diaries, kept between 1948 and 1964. Some diaries also contain clippings, notes, drafts of her writings, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are also a few personal notes in a 1963 notebooks filed in Series I.8: Other Notes and Notebooks.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This diary is accessible, but please take care that the lock remains open during use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some portions of this were used as a creative journal, and the portion from 1956 was to record her emotions during the writing of Chocolates for Breakfast. Items inserted loosely inserted into the front of the diary have been removed and housed in an appropriate folder. See Box 17, Folder 12.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes items inserted loosely inserted into the front of the diary: report card from Rosemary Hall, typescript of the story, "Veteran," with teacher's comments and grade, and clipping of Moore's first byline in the Greenwich Times. The diary itself is in Box 25.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers Moore's travels and her relationship with her family during 1956. Also includes telegrams from Moore's father, letters from Adam Kanarek, and other items. Includes draft and notes for "Heat."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Diary is used primarily for clippings, and also includes notes and outlines for Kathy.

did.physdesc: National Diary for 1961, with Officer of the Medical Examiner Sticker on Front

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This diary served both as a diary and a writing notebook. It includes drafts and notes for Kathy, Northscape, and several short stories and plays. There is a table of contents in the front of the volume. This volume also contains her last diary entries: entries and notes about her pregnancy and the birth of her son, and entries from 1964, including an entry for June 7th. This volume was used as evidence by the Office of the Medical Examiner, and the printed form sticker from the office is still affixed to the front of the volume.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This diary is missing its spine and the binding is quite fragile. It is accessible at this time, but please handle with care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Moore's drivers' license and passport.

did.unittitle: Subseries III.4: Financial, Tax, and Legal Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moore maintained a set of financial, tax, and legal files that are primarily related to her failure to pay taxes in 1957. This led to ongoing issues with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in the United States. These files include correspondence, forms, subpoenas, warrants, notices of judgment, tax returns, bank statements, royalty reports, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A savings account book, a file on medical expenses, and a file of receipts also pertain to Moore's finances during this period.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File includes correspondence, forms, subpoenas, warrants, notices of judgment, tax returns, bank statements, receipts, and royalty reports. These are related to Moore's failure to pay income tax in 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Medical bills, and list of medical expenses for 1958.

did.unittitle: Receipts--Columbia University, New York City, Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains school files from both Rosemary Hall and Barnard College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rosemary Hall files include school notebooks and a school magazine. There is an additional report card in Subseries III.2: Diaries (with the gray "ledger" diary). Moore's class photographs are filed in Series IV: Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Barnard College files include correspondence and other materials related to the submission of Moore's senior thesis and her progress towards the completion of her degree, as well as a copy of her senior thesis, other academic papers, notes, a yearbook, and Moore's diploma.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With notes on French, Grammar, History, English, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file includes correspondence and other records pertaining to Moore's progress towards the completion of her degree, including the completion of her senior thesis. The file includes transcripts, reports of standing, and bursar's receipts, as well as correspondence with Professors Burrell and Mundy, as well as the Registrar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file includes a history exam with a note from Professor John Mundy, papers, notes, and pages 136-150 of a corrected typescript of Prophets Without Honor.

did.unittitle: Barnard College--Senior Thesis--"Towards an Existentialist Interpretation of History"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a working draft and the final copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moore is listed with the Class of 1957 but there is no school portrait of her in the yearbook. There is an unidentified photogaph of her on page 64.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains five sketchbooks, and a few additional artworks and drawings. One of the items contains a montage of characters from Chocolates for Breakfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pencil sketches and poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Figures, faces, hands, legs, etc. Primarily in pencil, one in color.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pencil portraits. One nude, a few include two figures. One entitled, Figures, faces, hands, legs, etc. Primarily in pencil, one in color.The Co-Eds."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 pastels of a house, 1 of a girl's face. Draft letter in pencil related to Pigeons of St. Marks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Items in ink, pastel, watercolor, and pencil. Various subjects.

did.unittitle: Montage of Characters and Settings from Chocolates for Breakfast

scopecontent.p: Various pages of sketches and drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 items: a portrait of a girl (in color), a city scene (unfinished, partially in color), and a sketch.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Travel notes for the Azores, Lisboa, Gilbraltar, Naples, Pompeii, and Palermo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains both personal and professional photographs of Moore and Moore's family.

did.unittitle: Subseries IV.3: Family and Miscellaneous Photographs

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs of Moore's family, as well as additional photographs of Adam Kanarek and some photographs of his family. There are also some unidentified photographs, perhaps of family, in this subseries.

did.unittitle: Series VI: Literary Agent's Catalog of Archival Collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a copy of the literary agent's catalog of the collection available for purchase. The catalog includes detailed information and subject analysis on correspondence, diaries, manuscripts, and other materials in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Please note that most of the interviews described in the catalog on pages 43-44 were never received by the Rare Book & Manuscript Library. There is material related to interviews with Jonas Mekas and Michael "Dandy Kim" Caborn-Waterfield in Series VIII: Digital Materials.

did.unittitle: Literary Agent's Catalog of Archival Collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a copy of the catalog created for the collection by the literary agent representing Kevin Kanarek. It contains more detailed content information about many items in the collection. Note that the interviews listed in the catalog have not yet been received at Columbia University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a web site capture of the Chocolates for Breakfast website, http://chocolatesforbreakfast.info/, created by Moore's son, Kevin Kanarek. Many (but not all) of the photographs of Moore, as well as editions of the book, are of materials contained in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The archived site is here:http://chocolatesforbreakfast.info/

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes two audio files and one transcript of Kevin Kanarek's interviews with persons related to Moore. There is an audio file for an interview with Jonas Mekas. There is an audio file and a corresponding transcript for an interview with Michael "Dandy Kim" Caborn-Waterfield (the model for "Andrew Neville" in Chocolates for Breakfast); the transcript is available digitally as a pdf and a printed copy of the file has been placed in Box 19 Folder 13.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series also includes clips of two interviews on subjects related to Moore. Both were done by outside sources, and may be available elsewhere. The first is a video clip of Courtney Love speaking about how she was named after Courtney Farrel, the protagonist of Chocolates for Breakfast, giving her reading of the story, and discussing the overlap between the book and her own life (from VH1, 2010). The second is an audio clip of Jonas Mekas discussing his association with Edouard (Yves) De Laurot, including de Laurot's wartime past and their short-lived collaboration on Mekas' first film, Guns of the Trees (from Web of Stories, 2013).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Digital files can be accessed upon request via a secure laptop in the Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Reading Room.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Digital files can be accessed upon request via a secure laptop in the Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Reading Room.
